As we have noted, the behaviour of \(e^x\) as \(x\rightarrow\infty\) is called exponential growth. In a similar manner we characterise the behaviour of the function \(e^{-x}\) as \(x\rightarrow\infty\) as exponential decay. The graphs of \(e^x\) and \(e^{-x}\) are shown in Figure 3.

FIGURE 3 \(y=\e^x\) and \(y=\e^{-x}\)

Exponential growth is very rapid and similarly exponential decay is also very rapid. In fact \(e^{-x}\) tends to zero so quickly as \(x\rightarrow\infty\) that, no matter how large the constant \(K\) is, \[ \quad x^K\e^{-x}\rightarrow 0\quad \text{as}\quad x\rightarrow\infty \]  The next Task investigates this.
